title: Health Evaluation in African Americans Using RAS Therapy
description_brief: The purpose of this study is to determine if telmisartan, an FDA approved blood pressure medication, may also have beneficial effects on Alzheimer's disease prevention in African Americans, who are at high risk for Alzheimer's disease.
description_detailed: This study will assess if telmisartan, an FDA approved blood pressure medication, may also have beneficial effects on Alzheimer's disease (AD) prevention in African Americans, who are at high risk for Alzheimer's disease. Blood pressure medications known as angiotensin-receptor blockers have been associated with reduced risk of Alzheimer's in Caucasians because they act on the renin-angiotensin system (RAS), a key regulator of blood pressure in the body and the brain. The drugs appear to slow the progression of the disease by affecting flow of blood and the amount of plaque in the brain, but these benefits have not been tested in African Americans. The investigator will evaluate if telmisartan is able to influence the renin-angiotensin system in the brain and produce favorable effects on brain blood flow and enzymes that cause the brain plaques in Alzheimer's disease.The investigator will assess the mechanism by which telmisartan modifies the brain renin angiotensin system, cerebrospinal fluid amyloid-β, cerebral blood flow (CBF) and inflammatory markers in hypertensive African Americans.

participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: Participants were recruited from the Wesley Woods Health Center, Emory Alzheimer's Clinical Research Unit (ACRU), and the Emory Brain Health Center in Atlanta, Georgia, USA. Participant enrollment began April 2015 and all follow-up assessments were completed by April 15, 2022.

groups.title: Telmisartan 20mg
groups.description: African American participants with untreated or treated hypertension and at high risk for Alzheimer's disease (AD) who were randomly assigned to receive 20 mg of telmisartan to be taken orally once a day before bedtime, for a duration of 8 months.

groups.title: Telmisartan 40mg
groups.description: African American participants with untreated or treated hypertension and at high risk for Alzheimer's disease who were randomly assigned to receive 40 mg of telmisartan to be taken orally once a day before bedtime, for a duration of 8 months.

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: African American participants with untreated or treated hypertension and at high risk for Alzheimer's disease who were randomly assigned to receive a placebo to match telmisartan to be taken orally once a day before bedtime, for a duration of 8 months.

milestones.comment: Four participants in the Telmisartan 20mg group, 1 participant in the Telmisartan 40mg group, and 2 participants in the Placebo group were withdrawn from study medication prior to completing 8 months of treatment. These participants attended the Month 8 study visit and are considered as completing the study.

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcomeMeasures.title: Concentration of Angiotensin Converting Enzyme (ACE 1)
outcomeMeasures.description: The cerebrospinal fluid renin-angiotensin system (RAS) was assessed by measuring levels of angiotensin metabolites in a 1 milliliter (mL) sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). ACE 1 helps to regulate blood pressure by converting angiotensin I to angiotensin II.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: This analysis includes participants who completed 8 months of study treatment, attended the Month 8 study visit, and had a sufficient sample of CSF collected. The amount of CSF collected fluctuated and some samples were not of adequate quantity to be used for every lab measurement. In some cases, participants had an unsuccessful or inadequate lumbar puncture at Baseline and then had a successful lumbar puncture at the Month 8 visit.

outcomeMeasures.title: Concentration of Angiotensin Converting Enzyme 2 (ACE 2)
outcomeMeasures.description: The cerebrospinal fluid renin-angiotensin system (RAS) was assessed by measuring levels of angiotensin metabolites in a 1 milliliter (mL) sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). ACE 2 regulates levels of circulating angiotensin II. ACE 2 increases during illness and with Alzheimer's disease.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: This analysis includes participants who completed 8 months of study treatment, attended the Month 8 study visit, and had a sufficient sample of CSF collected. The amount of CSF collected fluctuated and some samples were not of adequate quantity to be used for every lab measurement. In some cases, participants had an unsuccessful or inadequate lumbar puncture at Baseline and then had a successful lumbar puncture at the Month 8 visit.

outcomeMeasures.title: Cerebrospinal Fluid Amyloid β40
outcomeMeasures.description: Levels of amyloid β40 (Aβ40) in the cerebrospinal fluid were measured using LUMIPULSE® technology. The relationship between Aβ40 is non-linear with moderate levels showing the highest risk of future cognitive decline in some studies.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: This analysis includes participants who completed 8 months of study treatment, attended the Month 8 study visit, and had a sufficient sample of CSF collected. The amount of CSF collected fluctuated and some samples were not of adequate quantity to be used for every lab measurement. In some cases, participants had an unsuccessful or inadequate lumbar puncture at Baseline and then had a successful lumbar puncture at the Month 8 visit.

outcomeMeasures.title: Levels of Cerebrospinal Fluid Amyloid β42
outcomeMeasures.description: Levels of amyloid β42 (Aβ42) in the cerebrospinal fluid were measured using LUMIPULSE® technology. Decreases in concentrations of amyloid β42 are indicative of a decrease in cognitive function.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: This analysis includes participants who completed 8 months of study treatment, attended the Month 8 study visit, and had a sufficient sample of CSF collected. outcomeMeasures.title: Matrix Metalloproteinase (MMP) Frequency
outcomeMeasures.description: Matrix metalloproteinase inflammatory markers will be examined in CSF.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: MMP was not analyzed because since developing the protocol for this study much has been learned about inflammatory cytokines and chemokines as AD preclinical biomarkers. The biological assay menu options for group analyses changed to include only those that have been shown to be related to disease state and likelihood of progression. The marker MMP was removed from the preplanned menu of inflammatory markers by the manufacturer and having MMP analyzed independently was cost prohibitive.

outcomeMeasures.title: CSF-Soluble Platelet-Derived Growth Factor Receptor Beta (sPDGFRβ)
outcomeMeasures.description: Soluble Platelet-Derived Growth Factor Receptor Beta (sPDGFRβ) is a marker of breakdown in the blood brain barrier. Increased levels of sPDGFRβ indicate cognitive dysfunction.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: This analysis includes participants who completed 8 months of study treatment, attended the Month 8 study visit, and had a sufficient sample of CSF collected. The amount of CSF collected fluctuated and some samples were not of adequate quantity to be used for every lab measurement. In some cases, participants had an unsuccessful or inadequate lumbar puncture at Baseline and then had a successful lumbar puncture at the Month 8 visit.

groups.description: African American participants with untreated or treated hypertension and at high risk for Alzheimer's disease who were randomly assigned to receive 20 mg of telmisartan to be taken orally once a day before bedtime, for a duration of 8 months.

groups.title: Telmisartan 40mg

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: African American participants with untreated or treated hypertension and at high risk for Alzheimer's disease who were randomly assigned to receive a placebo to match telmisartan to be taken orally once a day before bedtime, for a duration of 8 months.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Structural Magnetic Resonance Imaging and White Matter Hyperintensities
outcomeMeasures.description: High-resolution anatomical images will be acquired using a 3D-Fast Spoiled Gradient Recalled Echo (FSPGR) Sequence. White Matter Hyperintensities (WMH) will be identified by a 3D T2 Fluid Attenuated Inversion Recovery (FLAIR) Fast Spin Echo sequence. The images will be co-registered using a within-subject inter-modal alignment between structural and perfusion images. T1-weighted Spoiled Gradient Recalled (SPGR) images will be used to identify cerebrospinal fluid and white and gray matter. Increased volumes of white matter hyperintensities indicate impaired cognitive function.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Arterial Spin Labeling-Magnetic Resonance Imaging
outcomeMeasures.description: Echoplanar T1 mapping scans will be used for image registration and a scout image of the head will be obtained in order to choose the appropriate location for spin labeling and flow imaging. Arterial Spin Labeling images will be acquired using a custom 3D stack of interleaved spirals fast spin echo sequences and will be averaged in order to improve the signal-to-noise ratio. Images will be interpolated and smoothed in a panel by using a 0.5-pixel, full-width, half-maximum Gaussian kernel. Regional perfusion will be quantified in each hemisphere and maps of cerebral vasoreactivity will be obtained by co-registration of perfusion and anatomical images.

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: Information on adverse events was collected beginning at the baseline assessment and continued through the final assessment at Month 8.
adverseEventsModule.description: Participants were asked if they had experienced specific, anticipated adverse events. There was also a field for reporting other adverse events that were not specified.

eventGroups.title: Placebo
eventGroups.description: African American participants with untreated or treated hypertension and at high risk for Alzheimer's disease who were randomly assigned to receive a placebo to match telmisartan to be taken orally once a day before bedtime, for a duration of 8 months.

limitationsAndCaveats.description: Unanticipated expenses related to the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic resulted in less funds toward the end of this study impacting the post processing of neuroimaging scans.The researchers are submitting for additional funding for imaging processing and analyses, as well as searching for an expert who is available to perform imaging processing. Results for the magnetic resonance imaging outcomes will be reported as soon as possible.

explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is telmisartan — an orally available angiotensin II type 1 receptor blocker (ARB) with partial PPAR-γ agonist activity. Preclinical and epidemiologic evidence suggests telmisartan can reduce amyloid accumulation, neuroinflammation, and cognitive decline, and a population study identified telmisartan as a candidate drug associated with reduced Alzheimer's risk in African Americans. These actions target AD-related pathology rather than only providing short-term symptomatic cognitive enhancement or treating neuropsychiatric symptoms, so it best fits the 'disease-targeted small molecule' category. citeturn0search3turn0search1

Act: Key extracted trial details — drug: telmisartan (tested at 20 mg and 40 mg in the listed trial) vs placebo; study title: Health Evaluation in African Americans Using RAS Therapy (NCT02471833 / Emory University). Telmisartan is a small-molecule antihypertensive (ARB) with reported PPAR-γ activity that may mediate neuroprotective and anti-amyloid effects. citeturn0search6turn0search3

Reflect: Classification check — telmisartan is not a biologic (e.g., monoclonal antibody) nor is it being used solely as a symptomatic cognitive enhancer or for neuropsychiatric symptom relief in this study; instead it is repurposed to affect AD-relevant biology (amyloid, inflammation, vascular risk). Therefore 'disease-targeted small molecule' is the correct category. Note ambiguity: the trial is a prevention study in a high-risk population (African Americans) and telmisartan's mechanisms include blood-pressure lowering and pleiotropic metabolic/PPAR-γ effects; some benefit could be mediated indirectly via vascular risk reduction, but the preclinical and epidemiologic rationale cites direct anti-amyloid and anti-inflammatory effects. citeturn0search1turn0search2

Web search results (sources consulted): 1) Population-based discovery identifying telmisartan as a candidate for AD prevention in African Americans (Cheng et al., Alzheimer's & Dementia). citeturn0search1 2) Preclinical/mechanistic studies showing telmisartan's PPAR-γ activity and prevention of Aβ-induced cognitive decline. citeturn0search3turn0search2 3) Clinical reporting and small trials of telmisartan in hypertensive patients with AD (human studies assessing cognition and biomarkers). citeturn0search4turn0search8 4) Trial listing for 'Health Evaluation in African Americans Using RAS Therapy' (NCT02471833) showing telmisartan 20 mg / 40 mg vs placebo, sponsored by Emory University. citeturn0search6
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial drug is telmisartan, an angiotensin II type 1 receptor blocker (ARB) that also has partial PPAR-γ agonist activity; preclinical and epidemiologic evidence indicate it may reduce amyloid accumulation, phosphorylated tau, and neuroinflammation and also acts via blood-pressure/vascular risk reduction and metabolic effects. These mechanisms span CADRO categories Amyloid beta (A), Inflammation (F), Vasculature (K), and Metabolism/Bioenergetics (J), so the intervention is best classified as multi-target. citeturn0search3turn0search1turn0search6.

Act: Key extracted details — drug: telmisartan (oral small molecule, ARB with PPAR-γ activity); trial: Health Evaluation in African Americans Using RAS Therapy (NCT02471833) testing telmisartan 20 mg / 40 mg vs placebo; rationale: population pharmacoepidemiology and Mendelian randomization linking telmisartan/PPAR-γ to reduced AD risk in African Americans, plus preclinical data showing reduced Aβ, p-tau and neuroinflammation. These indicate effects on multiple CADRO domains rather than a single, specific AD target. citeturn0search4turn0search0turn0search6.

Reflect: Classification check — because telmisartan's mechanisms include direct actions relevant to amyloid/tau pathology (A), anti-inflammatory effects (F), vascular risk modification (K), and metabolic/PPAR-γ effects (J), the most specific CADRO assignment is R) Multi-target. If one had to force a single-domain label it could be A) Amyloid beta or F) Inflammation, but that would omit other clearly relevant mechanisms; therefore R) Multi-target best represents the trial. Confirmed.
